snippet.title: South east Australia warned to brace for a 'major winter storm' this weekend
snippet.content:
Waves crash into Wallaroo beach 0:35
Waves crash into Wallaroo beach. Video: Jake Selder
August 5th 2017 11 hours ago /display/adelaidenow.com.au/Web/Advertiser/AN SA News and Photos/
A BoM severe weather warning issued at 10.55pm on Saturday.
Paul Purcell, Jade Gailberger, Josephine Lim
Share
THE storm has well and truly arrived - with a raintank smashing into the roof of a Sandergrove home, and the rest of the state being lashed with gale force winds, thunderstorms and heavy rains. A cold front moved eastwards across the state on Saturday and a vigorous westerly airstream will continue over the Adelaide Metropolitan, Mount Lofty Ranges, Lower Eyre Peninsula, Yorke Peninsula, Mid North, Kangaroo Island, Lower South East and parts of the Murraylands and Upper South East districts. However, the Bureau of Meteorology cancelled a severe weather warning for West Coast, Eastern Eyre Peninsula and Riverland districts at 10.55pm on Saturday. Damaging wind gusts of 90-100 km/h are still possible - associated with showers and thunderstorms. Heavy rainfall in the Mount Lofty Ranges may lead to flash flooding. The SES have advised all South Australians south of Port Pirie to stay indoors and away from windows, warning "you are in danger from flying debris, falling trees and downed powerlines". "Roads may be dangerous, do not travel unless absolutely necessary." READ THE LATEST SES WARNING ISSUED AT 7.50PM BELOW
A car hit a tram at the Bonython Park station just after 8pm on Saturday night.
No one was injured and the tram had minor damage.
Emergency services on the scene of a collision between a car and tram near the Bonython Park Tram stop on Port Rd. Picture: Matt Loxton/AAPSource:News Corp Australia The wild winds also led to a rainwater tank breaking its moorings and crashing into the roof of a Sandergrove house in the state's south east. The owner of the home, who didn't want to be named, said the half-full tank rolled down a hill, through a fence before smashing into their roof. "It's horrendous, absolutely horrendous," the woman said. "It is like being in a cyclone". Fortunately no one was hurt. Meanwhile, Port Elliot resident Abbie Milnes returned to her home from Adelaide on Saturday afternoon to find a veranda had partially collapsed. "It can't be fixed at the moment, but the worst of it seems to have passed, so so far all good,'' she said.
Netballers brave the storm on Kangaroo Island 0:16
Netballers brave the storm on Kangaroo Island. Credit: Facebook/Shauna Black
August 5th 2017 12 hours ago /display/adelaidenow.com.au/Web/Advertiser/AN SA News and Photos/
Locals reported fallen trees across the metropolitan area, including Bedford Park, Meadows, West Beach, Noarlunga and Aldgate while there was localised flooding in Aberfoyle Park, Para Vista and O'Sullivans Beach. A tree fell across Shepherds Hill Rd at Eden Hills, prompting SES and MFS to ask motorists to avoid the area. Small power outages in Inneston, Stenhouse Bay, Hatherleigh,Warradale and Salisbury affected around 300 properties.
The weather bureau warned damaging winds averaging 55-65 km/h are possible over coastal parts and at elevated parts of the warning area, reaching up to 90-125 km/h. Locations which may be affected include Adelaide, Port Lincoln, Kingscote, Cleve, Maitland, Mount Gambier, Port Pirie, Clare, Murray Bridge, and Naracoorte. A wind gust of 91 km/h was reported at Strathalbyn at 5:30 pm. Neptune Islands recorded damaging winds averaging 69km/h with gusts reaching 106km/h on Saturday afternoon. Cape Borda on Kangaroo Island received nearly 23mm of rainfall since 9am on Saturday while closer to Adelaide Kuitpo 14mm.
State Emergency Service volunteers have spent Saturday filling sandbags in preparation for strong winds and possible flooding later today. The SES has already received more than 61 phone calls and is gearing up for a busy night. Sandbags will also be available at 10am on Sunday across six SES units. ■ Enfield SES Unit - Hoods Rd, Northfield ■ Noarlunga SES Unit - Corner of Lindsay and Brian roads, Londsale ■ Metro South SES Unit - 33 Beagle St, Lynton ■ Campbelltown SES Unit - 141 Montacute Rd, Campbelltown ■ Mount Barker SES Unit - 14 Simper Cres, Mount Barker ■ Port Adelaide-Enfield council depot - Willochra St, Largs North On Saturday, SES Mt Barker unit operations response manager Stuart Catt said they had 30 cars come through in the first two and a half hours. "Today is actually rather busy," he said.
SES volunteers at Mt Barker help Adelaide Hills residents prepare for the incoming storms 0:13
SES volunteers at Mt Barker fill sandbags in readiness for a cold front that was expected to bring damaging winds and cause flooding in the Adelaide Hills on Saturday.
August 5th 2017 17 hours ago /display/adelaidenow.com.au/Web/Advertiser/AN SA News and Photos/
"We've gone through roughly four tonnes of sand already." Mr Catt said the SES was encouraging people to prepare for 80mm of rain across the Mt Lofty Ranges as predicted by the Bureau of Meteorology. "There could be localised thunderstorms with severe wind as well," he said. "We're actually really glad that people are turning up and being prepared because it means the workload during the storm will be less for us." Mr Catt said during the storm, people should stay indoors and away from trees. "If it does get wet, call 132500 or if there is water in your house call triple-0," he said. "We are on standby for tonight and tomorrow and possibly into Monday morning at this stage.
A BoM severe weather warning issued at 10.55pm on Saturday.Source:The Advertiser Mt Barker resident Terry was at the SES collecting sandbags and said she experienced flooding in her garage a few weeks ago as well as last winter. "I thought I should do something about it," she said. Stirling father Michael Newbury, 41, said his family were preparing for the heavy rainfall by using sandbags to prevent water run-off from the road going down their driveway. "Last September we lost an entire cliff at our house and we spent seven months not living at home and having a team of bulldozers rebuild it," he said. "We're just making sure it doesn't collapse again. "We've got hoses on the lawn siphoning the water off to stop the water building up there and we've tried to clear away anything that could get blown away in the wind me do damage. Mr Newbury had also cleared away trees and branches from around his house so "nothing could hit it". The Bureau advises you should: ■ Move vehicles under cover and away from trees ■ Secure or put away loose items around your property ■ Stay indoors and keep away from widows when conditions are severe. Bureau of Meteorology senior forecaster Tom Boeck said there will be a brief relief on Saturday morning but another front moving eastwards across the state will bring heavy showers and thunderstorms by midday Saturday. "Winds will be strong and gusty, we will definitely be seeing an increase in the severity of winds," he said. On Sunday, a low pressure system developing south of Mt Gambier will bring another bout of rain, thunderstorm and small hail to south of the Barossa Valley. Adelaide temperature will only reach a maximum of 14C. Over the weekend until Tuesday, Mt Lofty is expected to receive up to 70mm rainfall in total, with 40mm over the south coast district. The wet weather will ease on Monday.
SKY NEWS Weather: Major winter storm 4:07
SKY NEWS Weather: Major winter storm
August 4th 2017 2 days ago /display/newscorpaustralia.com/Web/NewsNetwork/Network News/National/
Originally published as

Metro South SES Unit - 33 Beagle St
